paradigmatic 'old' of institutionalised activism carried out by
political parties and trade unions since at least the Industrial
Revolution. [Thinking about political [activism from]{.mark} the
perspective of **[grand narratives]{.mark}** and **ideologies**---as
well as of communist theories of comprehensive social change---has
[**stimulated** social scientists to]{.mark} regard the success of a
given mobilisation as dependent upon the attainment of certain
predetermined goals (Maeckelbergh 2011), such as a revolution that will
[**dismantle capitalism** and implement]{.mark} a **[new mode of
production]{.mark}**. Yet, seeking a revolution as the ultimate goal
often **assumes** that any **means are** valid **to reach** a more
egalitarian and **classless society**. Unlike this paradigm,
**[prefigurative politics refrain,]{.mark}** for instance,
**[from]{.mark} [using authoritarianism]{.mark}** to build a democratic
society.]{.underline}

Anthropology has shown a long-standing interest in prefigurative
politics since this concept's first links with social movements. Mostly
through the work of anthropologists-cum-activists, prefiguration has
been approached alongside themes dear to the discipline, such as social
organisation, globalisation, inequality, social change,
community-building, and the ways in which everyday lives are lived.
While political scientists and sociologists have mostly concentrated on
political strategies by drawing parallels between several cognate social
movements, anthropologists have employed participant observation to
explore particular movements, collectives, and networks. In such manner,
they have produced a nuanced understanding of how prefiguration takes
place on the ground---without losing sight of its shortcomings.

Due to ethnographers' particular attention to prefigurative politics in
Europe and the United States, the existing body of literature may convey
the idea that prefiguration thrives particularly in the Global North.
Existing analyses have also tended to focus on disruptive, contentious
politics. By contrast, fewer studies stress the pertinence of
prefigurative practices in the everyday lives of people in the Global
South, and of those who are not full-time protesters. Even fewer have
considered how right-wing activists also mobilise prefiguration. While
scholars generally agree on what constitutes prefigurative politics,
some highlight an apparent paradox when the anarchist-inspired
principles underlying prefiguration are mobilised by activists who are,
content-wise, anything but anarchists. Other scholars, in turn,
accentuate prefiguration as a political strategy that can be similarly
deployed by activists advancing progressive as much as conservative
content. Lastly, as I will discuss, several researchers have used
prefiguration as a rather problematic umbrella term to label which
movements and forms of activism have a prefigurative character and which
ones have not.

To explore the historical and current significance of prefigurative
politics, as well as its limitations, this entry analyses how this
concept and the practices it designates have come to bear relevance
among those who oppose representative democracy, build small-scale
politically organised entities as horizontal micropolities, and embody
alternative lifestyles. Questioning the seeming straightforwardness of
the divide between the new and old lefts and bringing right-wing
movements to the discussion, this entry provides anthropologists and
non-academics with a gateway to better understand the pervasive
practices that aim to turn activism into laboratories from where people
foster change by experimenting with new socialities.

The concept of prefiguration is often credited to Carl Boggs (1977) to
describe the logics and practices of left-wing movements that, mostly
since the 1960s, opposed Leninism and the working-class politics aimed
at structural reform. Yet, little did Boggs know that the term had been
previously used by Augustine in the 4th century BCE to explain a key
tenet of Christianity. [Examining the fall of lust-laden Rome,
[Augustine]{.mark} (\[1470\] 1998) [pointed]{.mark} out that, [to
enjoy]{.mark} spiritual [salvation and avoid]{.mark} collective
[perishing]{.mark}, people should resign their paganism and commit to
charity and moral integrity. Only by [prefiguring a]{.mark} divine
[beatitude]{.mark} could one near a state of holiness [to be]{.mark}
partially [enjoyed]{.mark} in the present and fully realised in the
future]{.underline} (Scholl 2016, 321; Buts 2019, 17).

of God's conduct, centuries later, Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels

bourgeoisie and bringing an end to class struggle. [Moving [away from
prefig]{.mark}uration, [the Communist manifesto]{.mark} (1848)
[urged]{.mark} proletarians [to fight]{.mark} the monopoly of the means

**[clashed]{.mark}** here: major streams of [Marxism ended up

Philippe Pignarre and Isabelle Stengers (2011) aptly illustrate the

conference would have constituted a more easily recognisable repertoire

standard protocols to either repress or ignore such expressions of

politicians, business people, and the police to curb the protest.

In this fashion, Seattle sought to depict neoliberal globalisation not

and deregulation measures that can be challenged and mocked by ordinary
people. This power of the crowds was later underscored by the motto 'we
are the 99%', made famous by the 2011 Occupy Wall Street movement, via
the argument according to which the majority of the world's population
cannot pay for the mistakes of the upper-class minority.

The Seattle protests also consolidated prefigurative politics not as an

grassroots democracy, direct action, and the creation of alternative
micropolitical relations of power (Yates 2015a). Holding voluntary
working groups to set up tents in occupied squares, serving food to
participants, protecting them from police action, and keeping spaces of
protest clean work to turn hierarchical power relations into inclusive
and participatory practices.

### Alt---Prefiguration---2NC---Framework/AT: Utopian Fiat

#### Prefigurative fiat is legitimate---Everything is "utopian", but denial of the not-yet reifies the present as permanent and cedes ground to capitalist realism!

Simin **Davoudi '23**, Professor of Environmental Policy & Planning,

Accessed via the University of Michigan Libraries, \[cf\]

Others have warned about the colonization of planning by a 'creeping
pessimism' and an 'absence of hope for the future' (Bletter 1993, 47).
There seems to be a reluctance to imagine places that do not yet exist,
and to explore and advocate social and spatial transformations towards
better urban futures. [[The]{.mark} disastrous [**consequences**
of]{.mark} modernist **urban [planning]{.mark}** [along with
**utopia's**]{.mark} one **literal meaning** as 'no-place' appears to
have [assigned **utopian thinking** to]{.mark} the **[dustbin]{.mark}**
of planning ideas and discourses (Pinder 2022). However, while
**[modernist utopianism]{.mark}** has [lost]{.mark} its [appeal]{.mark},
'[the]{.mark} Utopian [impulse']{.mark} has [remained]{.mark} 'an
**[irrepressible]{.mark} part of human spirit'** (Sandercock 1998,
1).]{.underline} Amid the uncertainties and despairs, this utopian
impulse, as a key function of hope, helps us to see the existing
conditions not as how things are, but as how they are made to be, and
how they might be unmade. Such a capability is a vital driving force for
prefigurative planning as a collective process of performing the future
in the present.

In what follows, I sketch out the conceptual framework of prefigurative
planning by focusing on the interrelated concepts of prefiguration, the
not-yet, hope, and concrete utopia. Based on this, admittedly abstract,
framework, I suggest that prefigurative planning is a collective pursuit
of: negating the given, envisioning concrete utopias, and performing the
not-yet future in the present. I also suggest that, the space--time of
prefigurative planning is 'here and now' with relations of (un)care
cutting across its contents, processes and reflections. That, its
politics plays out in the interstices of everyday spatial practices and
combines reason with intuition and emotion. Throughout, I stress that
prefigurative planning is not about how to 'build that city on the
hill', but how not to give up the pursuit of a plural 'better cities'
with planning imagination.

Prefiguration has a long history in social movement scholarship and
activism. The use of the term can be traced back to anarchist writings
of the late nineteenth and early twentieth century (Springer 2014) and
the New Left of the 1960s / 1970s (Breines 1982) including Gramsci's
(1971) critique of the classical Marxist's abstract principles and its
focus on the structural determinants of change. In discussing how signs
of radical change are prefigured in the present, Gramsci shifted the
attention towards civil society's capacity and everyday struggles to
build the new in the shell of the old without limiting the new to the
boundaries of the old (Ince 2012). For Carl Boggs (1977, 2),
prefigurative politics is 'the embodiment, within the ongoing political
practice of a movement, of those forms of social relations,
decision-making, culture and human experience that are the ultimate
goal'. This is not simply about Gandhi's frequently cited injunction:
'be the change that you want to see', or 'practice what you preach'.
Rather, it is about 'reformulation of the means-ends distinction' (Van
de Sande 2013, 233) whereby one mirrors the other (Swain 2019). As I
discuss later, this focus on the journey instead of the destination also
distinguishes the utopianism of modernist planning from that of
prefigurative planning.

Prefigurative politics 'refers to a range of social experiments that
critique the status quo' (Cornish et al. 2016, 114) while at the same
time pursuing future 'alternative or utopic social relations in the
present' (Yates 2015, 1). Since the post-2008 social movements, such as
Occupy (Gordon 2018), it has gained a growing currency in a wide range
of literature from politics to psychology. In planning scholarship,
however, the concept has remained underdeveloped. This is intriguing
given the close affinity between prefiguration and the future-oriented
nature of planning. To close this gap, we need to critically engage with
the concept and explore its potentials for future directions of planning
theory, practice and education. With this paper, I am inviting planning
scholars and practitioners to a dialogue by putting forward a framework
for a prefigurative mode of planning that constitutes both the negation
of the given and the creation of alternatives.

Margaret Thatcher, the former British Prime Minister, summed up the
hegemonic metanarratives of our time by claiming that 'there is no
alternative' to the neoliberalised EUROPEAN PLANNING STUDIES 2279
capitalist order, and 'there is no such thing as a society' in the
individualized social relations. Much of the so called 'realities' of
our time are built on the taken-forgranted assumptions that, the
relentless pursuit of capitalist growth is the source of all good and
market transactions can solve all social and ecological problems. That,
profit-maximizing growth lifts everyone up and trickle-down economics
create levelled-up geographies. That, hedonistic consumption generates
happiness and wellbeing. That, the only true measure of progress is the
GDP. That, cities as 'growth machines' are better off if they roll out
financialised real estate development and become safe-deposit-boxes for
'anonymous, illicit money' (Fernandez et al, 2016:2457). And that,
public interest is served not by safeguarding social and environmental
values, but by boosting private, speculative urban development. In the
face of these entrenched assumptions, any dissenting voices are 'deemed
to be the act of lunatics, idealists and revolutionaries' (Jackson 2009,
14) and any progressive planning activity is undermined as being a
barrier to enterprise.

I will return to this, but first we need to remind ourselves that
utopian thinking is not new to planning. On the contrary, envisioning
better places runs through its history, motivating its early twentieth

garden city was, above all, a 'Social City'; a cooperative, commonwealth
alternative to the capitalist cities of the time. Much of the early
modernist urban planning was also in pursuit of creating utopia. The

needs of the many as well as those of the individual' (CIAM 1933).
However, the utopia of modernist planning was an ideal end-state,
designed and executed from the top down, by an 'elitist and alienating'
agenda (Ley and Mills 1993, 268). Much of it was inspired by Le
Corbusier's EUROPEAN PLANNING STUDIES 2281 model of scrapping the old,
unplanned, irrational city, and building on a blank canvas according to
a rigid blueprint drawn by perceived all-knowing expert planners
(Davoudi and Madanipour 2012). As Bauman (2003, 15) put it, the
modernist utopia 'is a vision of predesigned world, a world in which
prediction and planning stave off the play of chance'.

The search for shipping lanes and natural resources in the Arctic Ocean
was pursued by representatives of different nations until the Little Ice
Age, which lasted roughly from the late sixteenth until the early
nineteenth century, put a temporary halt to it. 6 The utopian narratives
of the Arctic were not, however, only linked to the spread of
mercantilism and modern political economy. With the spread of
nationalism in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, the utopian
narratives of the Arctic were harnessed to serve nation-building
practices, which were part of the greater political project bound to
Arctic utopianism: the legitimisation of the domination of a territory.

man who built the country. In the USA, after the purchase of Alaska, the
former US Treasury Secretary Robert John Walker argued for the purchase

reasons. In Scandinavia, the Arctic explorations of the national hero of
Norway, Fridtjof Nansen, played a decisive role in the separation of
Norway from Sweden in 1905.8 At this time, the Arctic served not only as
a measure of national greatness but also as an arena for heroism and the
advancement of Western material, technological and cultural superiority.
It was thus used in the process of legitimising the expansion and
assumed superiority of Western high-modernist ideologies, and the
gradually progressing frontier of the European "useful arts", which in
the nineteenth century came to be known as technology.9 This was the
role the Arctic came to play in Joseph Stalin's Soviet Union as well.

In the Soviet Union, Stalin's dreams of "the Grand North", and its role
as one of the main scenes in the rapid modernisation and
industrialisation of the country, were captured in the first and second

of these plans was to shift the Soviet Union's centre of economic
gravity to the north and to the east. 10

The advancement of three more general political projects: legitimising
the domination of territory, the propagation of high modernist ideology
and the establishment of mercantilism, with political economy as its
successor, has created different socio- historical conditions for the
constitution and mobilisation of power through utopian narratives in the
Arctic. At specific moments, there has been a belief in the attain-
ability of these narratives, through which they have gained legitimacy
similar to that of scientific knowledge. They have, however, frequently
proven to be unattainable, incompatible with the natural constraints
that persist in the region as well as with the available technological
capacities and social possibilities. That is why, despite the recurrent
mobilisations of power for the exploration of these utopian narratives,
the Arctic of the early twenty-first century is not the glorified
materialisation of human innovation, technological advancement and
national prosperity asserted by the utopian Arctic narratives.

The economic structures in the North are narrowly based, with a strong
tendency towards monoculture. There is also a lack of stable road and
societal infrastructures within the existing settlements. 12 The
unprecedented effects of human-induced global climate change are already
visible in the region to a greater extent than in others areas of the
globe, as the Arctic will experience and has, together with the
Antarctic Peninsula, experienced the greatest regional warming in recent
decades due to climate change.13 The effects of climate change are, and
will be, most strongly felt in coastal regions, where damage from ice
activity and the flooding of structures such as bridges, pipelines,
drilling platforms and hydro- power facilities pose a major economic
threat and present serious risks for exist- ing and future
development.14 Regardless of these dire consequences of global warming,
utopian narratives of the Arctic, which focus on the promise of easier
access to the presumed riches of the North, have in fact been revived.
The Arctic utopias thus not only persist but have become integral to the
politics of the region, giving license to geopolitical projects and
constituting social and political power.

interests into the forefront of Arctic politics. In May 2008, the five

Continental Shelf (CLCS). 20 Further, since 2007, all of the eight
Arctic Council-defined Arctic states have adopted new official policies,
through which they discuss the developmental potential of the region and
how they will participate in its harnessing and governance.21

Utopianism as political practice: negating and superseding the
boundaries where the real and the possible meet The definition of utopia
that I use as the analytical framework for this article differs from
traditional distinctions in utopian theory. I do not explore utopias as
forms of social criticism, portrayals of the ideal society or
descriptions of non-places, the constructed geographies of collective
imagination. Instead, I accept the broad ana- lytic definition of utopia
suggested by Ruth Levitas. The focus of my analysis is therefore on the
exploration of the desires created by certain conditions that have been
left unfulfilled.24 Consequently, I describe utopianism in this article
as the art of the possible, and understand utopias to be a part of the
fictive sphere of social and political life that liberate and open up
spaces of action. The constitutive force of the fictive in such a
utopian mode attunes visions to the future while masking existing
realties and the sacrifices required for their attainment. 25 The
traditional core of utopia, that is, the expression of the desire for a
better way of being and living, is thus present in my work, but my
analytic emphasis is on the aspects of utopianism, which constitute and
mobilise social power: the ways in which utopias are used to harness and
express human desires to motivate them into action. 26 The utopias I
analyse in this article are therefore not necessarily grandiose projects
or the idiosyncratic vision of an ideal society; rather, they operate
more modestly within specific areas in which the process of
utopia-making is, in itself, already important. 27 When one approaches
the study of utopias from a broad analytical viewpoint, the boundary
between what is considered to be utopian and what is considered to be
practical speculation in social and political practices becomes fragile.
This approach reveals the constitution of power that is characteristic
to the act of label- ling. This mode of discursive practice does not
just posit the utopian narratives as being possible or impossible;
rather, it is, in itself, an act aimed towards the domi- nation of the
future and the unknown.28 The question in the analysis of different
socio-historical conditions under which language, meaning and social
power interact is therefore one of not only the legitimacy of power but
also the power of legiti- macy.29 One example of such power that is
noted by Ruth Levitas is the contempo- rary dream of unlimited growth on
a planet with limited natural resources, which dominates the global
political agenda. When one takes into consideration the reali- ties that
this vision hides beneath its dominant material values, the purported
project of continuing economic growth appears utopian in the pejorative
sense, without pro- viding a truly alternative vision. Levitas
highlights the idea that when viewed from this perspective, if the
commitment to growth appears to be impossible to stop, we must not only
dream, but demand, the impossible.30 At certain times in history, the
Arctic has been represented as a particular Land of Cokaygne, marking
the beginning of a hope for the transformation of the existing reality
through not only wishful thinking but also wilful action. 31 These
Arctic dreams have included the raising of hope for a better way of
traveling, growing and governing. The geographical remoteness, extreme
climate and other geographic char- acteristics have made the Arctic
especially conducive for such utopian practices as the horizons of
utopias, literary as well as political, are normally located somewhere
in the future or in the realm of the geographically unknown and
inaccessible. 32 In this article, I am especially interested in
understanding how particular ideas and forms of knowledge have made
possible, comprehensible and legitimate certain political pro- jects in
the Arctic. At the heart of my analysis are inter-subjective meanings,
which make subjective intentions possible in the first place, and the
problem of how the boundaries of a legitimate discourse are delimited.33
The goal of this research is thus not so much to explain what has
happened, but rather to understand why Arctic uto- pian imaginaries have
at certain times facilitated the mobilisation and constitution of power.
In my analysis I follow a discursive practices approach, which focuses
on contextual factors that enable and empower subordinate discourses,
histories and ideas, to become fused through argument into new
discursive modalities and alterna- tive political paradigms. My aim is
thus to illuminate the social nature of these pro- cesses and to
investigate their implications for political practices. 34 The social
construction and mobilisation of power through the imaginary in the
Arctic The first professional explorer to reach the Arctic was most
likely Pytheas of Massalia in the fourth century BC. 35 He and many of
those who followed in his footsteps in the Middle Ages did not know what
to expect in the North, and they found lands they were not in search of.
These voyages were not primarily motivated by utopian narratives of the
Arctic. 36 The first time utopian narratives of the North led to the
mobilisation of political power dates to the turn of the fifteenth and
the sixteenth centuries and the modern age of discovery.37 One of the
major sources of utopian narratives of the Arctic at that time was
Inventio Fortunata: a travel log of Nicholas, a Franciscan friar from
Oxford, from 1360, which he is said to have presented to Edward III of
England.38 Nicholas described the Arctic as the site of the Garden of
Eden, with four rivers, the Tree of Life, and a well of eternal youth.
His narratives have been identified as being a synthesis of Norse
mythology and the geographical knowledge of Norse Greenlanders of that
time.39 Based on these fourteenth century utopian descriptions of the
North, the first explorer to successfully convince British merchants, as
well as King Henry VII, of the plausibility of finding a route to Cathay
through the North was John Cabot in 1496. The situational nature of
utopias, that is the persisting political and technical conditions at
the time of their utterance, and the connection of power mobilising and
constituting utopian imaginaries of the Arctic to the three previously
mentioned larger political projects are visible in the mobilisation of
the Arctic utopia from the very beginning. 40 John Cabot's Arctic
explorations were preceded by the discovery of America in 1492, as well
as by the 1493 commissioned papal bull that divided the oceans of the
known world between Spain and Portugal, and forced the other sea powers,
England and Holland, to find other routes of commerce. 41 Cabot's
failure to dis- cover the Northwest Passage did not end the search for
it and the general exploration of the Arctic. Following Cabot, there
were many others who sought after the routes and riches of the North and
who, with stories and false maps from their journeys, contributed to the
construction, communication and transformation of the Arctic utopian
narratives.42 One of these utopian narratives that persisted for three
centuries was that of the Strait of Anian. This fictive passage to the
Pacific was introduced to sixteenth century cartography by Gaspar de
Corte Real, who sailed to the Gulf of St. Lawrence from the Azores and
mistook it for a strait. The belief in the strait persisted even though
Jacques Cartier reached the Lachine Rapids in 1535 and proved that the
strait did not exist. Moreover, the area, which is now known as the
Bering Strait, was referred to as the Strait of Anian in 1579. Because
the Bering Strait was not discovered by Western explorers until 1728, it
is uncertain whether the reference was based on lost information or only
wishful thinking. In any case, it was not until 1769 that George
Vancouver's explorations decisively disproved the myth of the strait and
the desire for this imaginary place finally conceded to reality.43 With
the advancement of history and an expanding knowledge base, the
conditions under which language, meaning and social power interact
changed. Slowly, the Arctic desires of explorers, merchants and monarchs
were harnessed to serve the advancement of the political projects of
modernity, materialism and nationalism. 44 Joseph Stalin's Soviet Union
offers an excellent example of such processes. The Arctic and our
northern regions contain colossal wealth. We must create a Soviet
organization which can, in the shortest period possible include this
wealth in the gen- eral resources of our socialist economic structure.
--Joseph Stalin, 1932^45^ The North as the guiding light in the progress
of the Soviet Union During his years in exile in Siberia, Joseph Stalin
experienced first-hand the hard- ships of living in the Arctic as well
as the relatively inefficient ways in which the Tsarist government
administered the region. The geographical remoteness of the area, and
the natural obstacles to the economic exploitation of the Arctic,
provided him with the perfect opportunity for the material
legitimisation of the grand Com- munist utopian narrative that told of
the victory of human science over the natural world.46 Consequently, the
heroes of the dozen Soviet Arctic explorations that took place between
1932 and 1939 were portrayed as representatives of the giant steps
forward in the USSR's great march towards "the shining dreamland of the
socialist tomorrow", as John McCannon describes the imagined bright
Socialist future of the time. 47 In the words of the Soviet author and
political activist Maxim Gorky from 1937: "In the darkness of the polar
night, the sun of the human intellect now shines brightly".48 Conveyed
to a public audience by means of carefully manipulated words and images,
the Arctic eventually became a vital part of Stalinist Russia's mythic
land- scape. The Bolshevik government engineered enormous increases in
Russian settlements in the North as well as in mining and
industrialisation in the region. These measures aimed to extend Soviet
power across all of its northern territories as well as to advance
Stalin's primary goal of rapid industrialisation. 49 So powerful was
this Soviet high modernist ideology and utopian propaganda at the time
of industrialisation and modernisation that it led Dr. Bruce Campbell
Hopper, a professor of political science and Soviet expert at Harvard
University, to describe the status of Soviet affairs in the Arctic in
1935 as the "Soviet Conquest of the Far North": "The search for the
Northeast Passage to Cathay, which for four centuries stirred the
imagination of European mariners, has at last ended in triumph. We seem
at the beginning of a new phase of man's relations with the North".50
Once put into action, the blueprint for this Soviet Arctic dream was
executed by forced labour-camp manpower, which included the White Sea
Canal project that aimed to build a canal that would open shipping
between the Arctic Ocean and the Leningrad region, bypassing the Barents
and the Baltic Sea. Plans for such a canal had already been drawn up by
eighteenth century Czarist merchants. The achieve- ment of this plan
thus offered Stalin the opportunity to legitimise the superiority of the
new Soviet regime over the old Czarist one, which had never been able to
accomplish it. 51 The rapid forward march towards the realisation of
Soviet Arctic dreams was to a certain extent facilitated by the nearly
limitless ambition inherent in the dominant ideology of high modernism.
This belief, which borrows from the legitimacy of science and
technology, aspires to transform nature to suit all of man's purposes.52
The other part of the socio-historical context that enabled utopian
discourses to constitute and mobilise power in the Soviet Arctic was
supported by the general conditions that also enabled Joseph Stalin to
become the leader of Russia. These conditions included the ideological
utopian fanaticism that was embedded in Marxism and its international
nature, the chaos and violence of the First Word War, Lenin's murderous
dictatorship over the proletariat, as well as the rise of historical
materialism. 53\\ In the end, the rapid rate of change combined with the
lack of planning, prim- itive technology applied too quickly and the
authoritarian role of the Five-Year Plans created more suffering than
progress in the Soviet Arctic. The White Sea Canal, for example, was
built in only 18 months by prisoners from the Gulag prison camps, and an
estimated 25,000 of them lost their lives in the process. The canal
ultimately failed to serve its purpose because it was too shallow to
begin with, and the goods in the region continued to be delivered by
rail. 54 The inheritance of unfulfilled Soviet desires is also visible
in the stranded and eco- nomically unviable cities in the Russian
Arctic. 55 As this legacy of the mobilisa- tion of Soviet Arctic desires
shows, the dreams of rapid industrialisation through collectivisation
and Soviet technology turned out to be fuelled by utopian narra- tives
more than anything else. These narratives were constructed of mythical
ele- ments that were already packed with meanings and associations that
were separate from the material, social and technical realities of the
time. 56 The grandiose Soviet geopolitical projects in the Arctic were
legitimised and mobilised more by rhetoric and ambition than by actual
accumulated knowledge from the region itself. The power and appeal of
these projects seems to have been constituted fur- ther through the
conditions of national and international political uncertainty.57 These
contextual factors enabled and empowered subordinate utopian Arctic
narra- tives to become integrated through argument into the realm of
political discourse and possible politics at the beginning of the
twentieth century in the other Arctic countries as well. In the 1920s,
the Norman Wells oil deposit was discovered in the Mackenzie River in
Canada's Northwest Territories and was labelled as "the biggest oilfield
in the world". Oil exploration in the region started in the 1920s and
returned in the 1940s, but it came to a halt both times due to
geographical and climatic obstacles.58 The Alaska Highway, initiated
after the signing of the Alaskan Highway Act between the USA and Canada
in March 1942, was publicised as a means by which to move troops and
supplies to Alaskan military bases during the Second World War; how-
ever, it was never used for this purpose. Furthermore, in 1945, Canadian
officials who were responsible for the maintenance and control of the
parts of the road built on Canadian soil discovered that the road was
virtually impassable without major reconstruction, and it remained a
military road until Royal Canadian Engineers were able to rebuild it to
meet acceptable standards for public use in 1948.59 In Finland, the
large-scale forest cuttings in Lapland after WWII, which were used in
the rebuilding of the country, were based on the calculations of forest
engineers; this large-scale deforestation subsequently led to severe
environmental damage as well as damage to forest growth in the region.
60 What makes the case of the Arctic an especially intriguing one for
the study of how language, meaning and social power interact is that
despite the obstacles that the high modernist, national and economic
projects in the Arctic have faced in past decades, the utopian desires
about the region still persist. Indeed, they continue to drive and
mobilise political power in the region. Russia's President Dmitri
Medvedev, for example, stated in a speech in September 2008, "Our first
and main task is to turn the Arctic into a resource base for Russia in
the twenty- first century".61 The Kingdom of Denmark presented the
current and future state of the North in its 2011 Strategy for the
Arctic as follows: Climate change and technological developments are
also opening new possibilities for the Arctic. Among them is increased
access to the exploitation of oil, gas and minerals, but also new
shipping routes, which can reduce costs and CO 2 emissions by freight
between the continents ... Commercial opportunities in the Arctic are
enormous, not least for the Greenland, Faroese and Danish industries,
which to a great extent already possess the skills that will be far more
in demand with the development of the Arctic region. 62 After centuries
of unsuccessful attempts to realise utopian Arctic desires, the North-
ern regions of the world continue to be described as a realm of
potential economic and national prosperity as well as an arena for
heroism and technological advance- ment. The current utopian narratives
about the Arctic seem to be rooted in the same three dominant political
projects of state dominance over territory, materialist capi- talism and
high modernist ideology as the ones discussed earlier in this article.
At a time when the main organising principle of international relations
shows signs of shifting (at least partially) from an ethos of state
sovereignty to one of globalisation, these narratives are contested by
alternative interpretations. Nevertheless, especially under uncertain
conditions, such narratives liberate and open up the Arctic for spe-
cific types of action while shutting out alternatives. One of the
strongest advocates of these historically embedded utopian visions of
the future of the Arctic in the beginning of the twenty-first century
has been Stephen Harper, who has held the post of Canada's prime
minister since 2006. "Our North, Our Heritage, Our Future"63 Practising
and defending Canada's sovereignty in its Arctic territories, as well as
Arctic security, in general, have been several of the main agendas of
the country's Prime Minister, Stephen Harper, since he identified them
as among his central campaign issues when he ran for office in the
Canadian Federal Elections of 2006.64 In his vision of the future, the
wealth, glory and power of Canada would be constituted through the
development of its northern territories. Such desires for conquest of
the geographically changing Arctic, which some interpret as representing
the first signs of the dystopic environmental degradation that will
ultimately lead to the end of the age of man on earth, were already
present in Harper's speech opening Parliament's Second Session in
2007.65 "Canadians see in our North an expression of our deepest
aspirations: our sense of exploration, the beauty and the bounty of our
land, and our limitless potential".66 The most profound element in the
definition of utopia as used in this article is clearly present in the
above quote. That is, the North as the expression of Canadians' "deepest
aspirations" and "the limitless potential", which indicate desires
created by certain conditions that are not yet fulfilled. The
development of the "new opportunities" Harper acknowledges to be
emerging across the Arctic, but which he does not specify in the speech,
will, according to the subtitle of the printed text of the address,
strengthen Canada's sovereignty and place in the world. The old project
of legitimising the dominance of a territory is also present in this
address, in which Harper announced the development of a new,
comprehensive northern strategy for Canada. Canada's New Northern
Strategy titled "Our North, Our Heritage, Our Future", which came out in
2009, highlights actions that will be taken to meet the challenges and
opportunities of a changing Canadian North, "helping the North realise
its true potential as a healthy, prosperous and secure region within a
strong and sovereign Canada".67 All of the three underlying political
projects, sovereignty, high-modernist ideology and capitalist growth
economy, which have been embedded in the formulation of desires about
the Arctic since early-modern times, are present in the strategy. We are
a northern country. The True North is our destiny -- for our explorers,
for our entrepreneurs, for our artists. To not embrace the promise of
the True North, now, at the dawn of its ascendency, would be to turn our
backs on what it is to be Canadian. --Canada's Prime Minister Stephen
Harper, August 2008, Inuvik, Northwest. 68 In this strategy, the social,
cultural and aesthetic values that are associated with the North are
present, but the underlying desire for the future of the region, and the
rea- son for the need for new attention to the Arctic, comes through as
material and eco- nomic. "From the development of world-class diamond
mines and massive oil and gas reserves, to the growth of commercial
fisheries, to a thriving tourism industry that attracts visitors from
around the globe, the enormous economic potential of the North is being
unlocked".69 The above statement aims at the domination of the future
and the unknown by rhetorically building it in the present. It becomes
appar- ent, when one is acquainted with the current material,
technological and financial realities of the region that this narrative
of the prosperous North, put forward in the Canadian Arctic Strategy,
suppresses, and which would render these aspirations unattainable and
thus utopian. In 2011, instead of increasing the funding of its northern
educational institu- tions, the Stephen Harper-led government of Canada
cuts its funding to the interna- tional and interdisciplinary University
of the Arctic by two-thirds. 70 Additionally, the Canadian Coast Guard's
Amundsen icebreaker was unexpectedly dry-docked in Quebec in January due
to cracks in four of its six engines, halting planned research trips to
the Arctic Ocean.71 What is more, Stephen Harper's plan for funding new
icebreakers continues to shift due to the changing political and
economic condi- tions. In 2005, when he was the opposition leader,
Harper promised to build three new heavy icebreakers. Two years later,
as Prime Minister, he announced that six to eight ice-strengthened
Arctic offshore patrol ships would be constructed instead. In 2010, the
navy, to whom these icebreakers were assigned, scaled back the planned
size and speed of the ships. The vessels will be capable of just 17
knots, compared with the 29 knots of Canada's two-decade-old frigates.
Their capabilities will also be limited by the decision to build them as
ice-strengthened rather than icebreaking vessels. This means that the
hulls will not be strong enough to allow for Arctic operations between
November and July.72 Nevertheless, Prime Minister Harper con- tinues to
base his narratives of the Arctic on the specific desires embedded in
the kinds of high modernist, economic and nationalist political projects
that have been discussed here, rather than acknowledging and addressing
the unravelled realities and obstacles in the way of the fulfilment of
these dreams. "Canada's North is full of economic potential and
innovators continue to unlock development possibilities that bring with
them real economic benefits and long-term jobs for local residents".73
By continuing to use this rhetoric at a time of increased economic as
well as environmental uncertainty, Harper aims to gain dominance in the
development of the future of not only the (sovereign) Arctic spaces but
also that of the natural envi- ronment and of global as well as national
politics by fabricating it with pre-existing narratives at the present.
The rhetoric he uses is a part of the larger utopia of the unlimited
growth of material wealth on a planet with limited natural resources,
where the growing usage of non-renewable energy and the geographic
location of those sources in politically unstable zones, combined with
global warming, has increased the allure of the previously economically
unviable resources in the North. The dominance of this larger utopia in
the global socio-historical context enables the constitution and
mobilisation of power through utopian narratives of the Cana- dian
Arctic. Moreover, the dynamics of the changing Arctic continue to
frequently surprise natural scientists, and the science of climate
change evolves faster than the time in which reports can be published.
When the last assessment of the Intergov- ernmental Panel on Climate
Change was released in November 2007, studies a mere 14 months later
suggested that sea-ice melt, glacier retreat and food insecurity were
all more dire than the IPCC had predicted. 74 One of the main conditions
by which utopian narratives are able to gain legitimacy in the Arctic
seems therefore, yet again, to be that of uncertainty.75

Conclusion

At certain times, in specific socio-historical conditions, [[the
Arctic]{.mark} has worked as [a **blank screen** for]{.mark} the
[projection of desires]{.mark} for the future condition of the region
that has been presented as an already existing material
reality]{.underline}. [This practice of using utopian
narratives]{.underline} about the Arctic [to constitute and mobilise
power for the actualisation of desires]{.underline} dates back to the
Renaissance, but it [remains a part of the present-day
politics]{.underline} of the Arctic as well. In fact, the construction
and [[mobilisation]{.underline}]{.mark} of utopian projections of the
Arctic in the politics of the region [has been [connected to]{.mark} the
**advancement** of]{.underline} three more general political projects:
the legitimisation of the domination of a territory, the
[[**propagation** of]{.mark} high modernist
**[ideology]{.mark}**]{.underline} and the establishment of mercantilism
with modern political economy as its successor.

The advancement of technology, especially the rediscovery of the
cartography of the Ancient world, served to legitimise some of the
utopian narratives of the Arctic as scientific knowledge early on. This
is visible in the way in which the portrayal of the Arctic based on the
stories of Nicholas of Lynn persisted in Arctic cartography for decades.
A similar belief in the power of technology, and how it could harness
nature to fulfil all human desires also played a central role in the
mobilisation of the narratives of the "Great North" in the Soviet Union.

The Arctic, however, has not been the first or the only choice for the
fulfilment of the material desires of the high-modernist ideology,
nationalism and materialism. Another condition, which has enabled the
exploration of the material possibilities in the Arctic, has been the
lack of alternatives. John Cabot convinced English merchants and the
King to invest in the search for a route to Cathay through the North in
1496 because the papal bull commissioned in 1493 had divided the oceans
of the known world between Spain and Portugal, leaving no other option
to the other sea powers of the time than of seeking a route of commerce
in the North. This con- dition is also present in the current emergence
of the Arctic into the centre of international relations. The increased
usage of non-renewable resources has made the northern resources, which
will be harder to access than most of the other large deposits, even
with less permafrost on the Arctic Ocean, more lucrative.

[The [**most important** condition]{.mark} for utopian imaginaries of
the Arctic for the purpose of **mobilising** and **constituting power**
in the region [has]{.mark}]{.underline}, however, [[been]{.mark} that of
**[uncertainty]{.mark}**]{.underline}. First, it was the uncertainty of
geography; then, it was the uncertainty of the global and national
political conditions; and finally, it was the uncertainty of the
progress of global climate change and the organisation of the future
international order. [When looking at the role utopian narratives have
played]{.underline} in human engagement [with the Arctic]{.underline}
through history, it seems that [we are yet again living in a time when
scientific [**understanding** **lags**]{.mark} far [behind]{.mark}
political **[ambitions]{.mark}**]{.underline}. Thus, [the mobilisation
of political and economic support for projects in the [Arctic
depends]{.mark} heavily [on]{.mark} the [**construction** of]{.mark} a
range of **[utopian narratives]{.mark}**]{.underline}. As such,
contemporary Northern politics, including those of Canada's Prime
Minister Harper, reveal more about the prevailing desires and values in
international relations than about the material realities of the region,
just as it was with their predecessors since the fifteenth century.

which distinguish them from port cities elsewhere. [[In a]{.mark}

symbolized]{.mark} the ['gates to the world']{.mark}; in an economic

economy]{.mark}.]{.underline} In many ways, socialist ports were places
of exception: heightened contact with the rest of the world went hand in
hand with heightened control; the relative permeability of ports as

dissent.

This Forum aims to identify the specificity of [[socialist ports]{.mark}
by examining their functioning and [embedded]{.mark}ness [within
different networks]{.mark} [throughout]{.mark} the second half of [the
twentieth century]{.mark}.]{.underline} We include Yugoslavia in our
exploration of this topic, prior to the early 1960s, when it liberalized
its border regime and took on a leadership role in the Non-Aligned
Movement. Although excluded from the Socialist Bloc in 1948, it shared
many features with Socialist Bloc states, including its adherence to an
alternative ideology and political and economic system, a history of
friction with capitalist states, and highly regulated borders. We focus
on the locality (socialist ports as specific economic, political or
social sites, as spaces within cities), on the agents (e.g. national and
local authorities, workers and ship personnel within a highly
international working environment), on networks (between ports both
socialist and non-socialist, as well as the interface between ports and
other entities, such as railways) and on changes and continuities during
(economic, political, social) transformations.

"The Market" against "The Political"

[Much criticism]{.underline} of contemporary social and political life
involves the claim that we are, either actually or aspirationally,
dominated by the market. Wendy Brown [has]{.underline} famously
[associated neoliberalism with the desire to **marketize all domains**
of social life]{.underline} (Brown Reference Brown2015). Jamie Peck has
identified neoliberalism with an aspiration to frictionless market rule
(Peck Reference Peck2010). Wolfgang Streeck has described contemporary
capitalism as embodying the dominance of market logics over the
incompatible political logic of democracy (Streeck Reference
Streeck2014a; Reference Streeck2014b). Gerald Davis (Reference
Davis2009) has characterized the contemporary political condition of
Americans as that of being "managed by the market." In various forms and
various guises, [the dominance of markets in organizing social and
political life is decried as a **major source** of inequality and
exploitation]{.underline} in our contemporary experience. Much of this
work draws, explicitly or implicitly, on Polanyi's seminal intervention,
which identified the "stark utopia" of economic liberalism as involving
the aspiration to "\[run\] society as an adjunct to the market" (Polanyi
Reference Polanyi2001, 3, 60).

As commentators have noted, Polanyi's influential account in The Great
Transformation seems to contain an unresolved tension (see Block
Reference Block2003; Block and Somers Reference Block and Somers2014).
Over the course of the book, he frames his argument in divergent (and
potentially incompatible) ways. Thus he sometimes seems to claim that
running society "as an adjunct to the market" is practically
undesirable, as it will lead to the "demolition of society" (Polanyi
Reference Polanyi2001, 76). In this view, "the market" and "society"
have incompatible logics, so disembedding the market has deleterious
consequences. At other times, Polanyi seems to suggest that the economy
is always embedded in society. In this view, there is no such thing as
disembedding the market; even what was called "laissez-faire" was
actually "planned" and required ongoing state intervention (146--7). So
understood, Polanyi's work seems to claim that disembedding the market
is both dangerous (because society cannot bear being subjected to such a
self-regulating mechanism) and conceptually impossible (because such a
"self-regulating mechanism" is a fiction). It is not clear how these two
claims are meant to fit together.

Block and Somers have helpfully explored this ambiguity, arguing that
the second formulation, which they term the "always-embedded economy"
thesis, is Polanyi's most insightful discovery. In their view, Polanyi's
earlier formulation arises "from the Marxist conceptual framework that
had been the initial organizing framework for his book" (Block and
Somers Reference Block and Somers2014, 81). Over the course of writing
the book, his investigations caused him to move beyond this perspective
and develop the always-embedded economy thesis. Because he did not have
time to revise the book's argument before publishing, the text retains
both perspectives, despite their incompatibility (Block Reference
Block2003, 284--5; Block and Somers, Reference Block and Somers2014,
82).

Despite the thoughtfulness of this intervention, I suggest that a
similar (though somewhat more subtle) ambiguity remains even in the
analysis offered by Block and Somers. This ambiguity is evident in their
explication of the always-embedded economy thesis. When this thesis is
first introduced, it is said to involve the observation that "even
'free' market economies consist of cultural understandings, shared
values, legal rules, and a wide range of governmental actions that make
market exchange possible" (Block and Somers Reference Block and
Somers2014, 9). This, they claim, is a fundamental reality that
"\[e\]conomists deny" (9). Thus all claims to "disembed" the economy in
the name of the free market are deceptive. Although "market ideologues"
may claim that they are "setting the market free from the state," in
reality they are merely "re-embedding it in different political, legal,
and cultural arrangements, ones that mostly disadvantage the poor and
the middle class and advantage wealth and corporate interests" (9;
italics in original).

This persuasive view of embeddedness, however, is modified in their
subsequent exposition. In their later analysis of "the concept of the
always-embedded economy," Block and Somers describe this thesis as
entailing "that market societies must construct elaborate rules and
institutional structures to limit the individual pursuit of gain or risk
degenerating into a Hobbesian war of all against all" (Block and Somers
Reference Block and Somers2014, 94). The next sentence reaffirms this
viewpoint: "In order to have the benefits of increased efficiency that
are supposed to flow from market competition, these societies must first
limit the pursuit of gain by assuring that not everything is for sale to
the highest bidder" (94). Notice the subtle shift in meaning that the
concept of embeddedness undergoes in this passage. Initially, the
embeddedness thesis involved the claim that all market arrangements
(including those advocated by free market ideologues) involve different
forms of embeddedness. Yet in the second formulation, embeddedness is
identified specifically with rules and institutions that limit or
constrain profit-seeking activity. This reintroduces a normative
component into what was previously a descriptive claim. It is not simply
that markets are always embedded (in the sense that they rely on rules
and institutions) but that this embeddedness must constrain
profit-seeking activity (because the preservation of society requires
it).

This second formulation is in clear tension with the first. The first
presentation of embeddedness suggests that there is no such thing as
"the market." Markets always interact with legal and cultural
institutions that give them a particular shape. Thus, as observed above,
even "free market ideologues" are actually proposing alternative forms
of embeddedness. Yet throughout their analysis, Block and Somers also
speak of embeddedness as serving to protect society from "unmediated
market forces" (Reference Block and Somers2014, 10) and "unfettered
markets" (201). If markets are always embedded, however, such
formulations are incoherent. They imply that a disembedded market is a
real possibility (albeit an undesirable one).

This ambiguity is a legacy of the Polanyian framing with which
contemporary political theory needs to contend. Those drawing on
Polanyi, inheriting this unresolved tension, tend to shift between these
two different meanings of embeddedness. They sometimes argue that
markets cannot, as a factual matter, be disembedded (because they are
always governed by rules, institutions, etc.) and thus that the very
idea of free markets is incoherent. At other times, however, they
suggest that we should be wary of "unmediated market forces" because
they are incompatible with the flourishing of society (a claim that
relies upon the idea of an essential market logic that the first thesis
disavows). Clarifying the political nature of markets, and the meaning
of their embeddedness, is thus crucial to gaining clarity on
contemporary debates about their role in contemporary politics.

Material Markets as Sociotechnical Agencements

Much of the debate over market forms in contemporary life has been
conducted in terms of advocacy of or opposition to the free market. In
this view, markets naturally operate according to their intrinsic,
impersonal logics. Critics suggest that government intervention should
"tame" these markets, regulating away their most objectionable features
or restraining them to carve out a space for politics. Advocates hold
either that market logics spontaneously emerge in the absence of
political interference or that political intervention is necessary as a
supplement to ensure that markets function according to their true
competitive logic. Both approaches, however, participate in the
fundamental framing of markets contested in this paper. They suggest
that a natural or pure form of the market exists, prior to and outside
of political meddling.Footnote 5 They then envision forms of politics
that can either restrain or preserve the natural "logics" possessed by
market forms. Yet, as Block and Somers affirm, what is called the free
market by both apologists and critics is in fact constituted by a whole
host of political choices, conditions, and enabling devices.Footnote 6
The very designation free market is an attempt to occlude this reality,
framing the "neutral" market position as if it were apolitical and
technical and then opposing this to an "interventionist" position in
which politics contaminates or alters the logic of the market. It is
this very notion of an originary, natural market, freed from the
constraints of political judgment, that the perspective developed here
seeks to contest.

Callon develops a view of markets that depicts them not as abstract
mechanisms but as "collective calculating devices."Footnote 7 In this

material]{.underline}** "**[apparatuses]{.underline}**" [that

The notion of agencement has a complex lineage and lacks a single,
clear-cut definition. Caliskan and Callon define the term by stating
that "action, including its reflexive dimension which produces meaning,
takes place in hybrid collectives (Callon and Law Reference Callon and
Law1995), hereafter called sociotechnical agencements (STAs).
Sociotechnical agencements are comprised of human beings (bodies) as
well as material, technical and textual devices" (Caliskan and Callon
Reference Caliskan and Callon2010, 9). Though "agencement" has often
been translated as "assemblage" in academic literature, MacKenzie points
out that this effaces a helpful play on words present in the original
French. Agencement literally means "arrangement" and thus emphasizes
questions of material and technical configuration. On the other hand,
however, the term agencement possesses an obvious etymological link to
the notion of "agency" (MacKenzie Reference MacKenzie2009, 21; see also
Callon Reference Callon, Pinch and Swedberg2008, 38). An agencement, in
other words, is a particular material configuration (a "network") of
humans and nonhumans that possesses unique capacities to act in and with
the world. Seeing the agencement as the unit of agency helps us to focus
on the relationships among actors, competences, technologies, and
knowledge that make complex forms of distributed agency possible.
Viewing markets as particular types of "sociotechnical agencements" thus
directs our attention to all of these dimensions: to the materiality of
markets; the way they rely upon combinations of technologies,
discourses, and knowledges; and the way they facilitate and embody novel
forms of action. This notion suggests that [markets]{.underline}, like
other forms of sociotechnical life, [are more **open**]{.underline},
**[polyvalent]{.underline}**, [and **flexible** than traditional

which they equip agents are matters of deep political consequence. It
renders the development of any form of
"**[economization]{.underline}**," [including
**[marketization]{.mark}**]{.underline}, intelligible as an open process
that [[is]{.underline}]{.mark} "**[[historical]{.underline}]{.mark}**,
**[[contingent]{.underline}]{.mark}**, [[and
**disputable**]{.underline}]{.mark}" (Muniesa, Millo, and Callon
Reference Muniesa, Millo and Callon2007, 3).

Caliskan and Callon (Reference Caliskan and Callon2009; Reference

CONCLUSION

The purpose of this chapter was to scrutinize the relationship between
economic freedom and environmental performance. Whether economic freedom
is good or bad for the environment depends on how it affects incentives,
productive efforts, and effective resource use. Greater economic freedom
can both harm and help environmental performance. [It is a
**complicated** relationship]{.underline}, [but high economic freedom
**generally goes hand in hand** with high scores in the]{.underline}
**[E]{.underline}**nvironmental **[P]{.underline}**erformance
**[I]{.underline}**ndex.

[Economic freedom]{.underline}, [and]{.underline} the
[wealth]{.underline} that flows from it, [is **consistent**
with]{.underline}, [and **supportive** of]{.underline}, [a healthy
environment]{.underline}. [The environment usually benefits when a
larger percentage of land and property are **privately held** and
**protected**]{.underline} by a country's judicial system.
[Although]{.underline}, for example, [global carbon]{.underline} dioxide
[emissions have not decreased]{.underline},
**[g]{.underline}**reen**[h]{.underline}**ouse **[g]{.underline}**as
[[emissions]{.mark} [from developed economies]{.mark}]{.underline} such
as the EU and the US [have [fallen **despite** continued economic
growth]{.mark}]{.underline}. [[Tech]{.mark}nological developments in
many economies [have contributed to]{.mark} a **sharp [decline]{.mark}**
[in]{.mark} the [prices]{.mark} of renewable energy
technology]{.underline}, [which has [improved]{.mark} the economic
[conditions for **rapidly reducing**]{.mark} carbon dioxide emissions
**[globally]{.mark}**]{.underline}.

The research regarding the relationship between economic freedom and the
possible degeneration or improvement of the environment is still in its
infancy, and there are several avenues future research should take.
There is both a need for further probing into issues that have not so
far been addressed, such as discontinuities and non-linearities in the
relationship between economic freedom and the environment, and a need
for better methodology, especially taking causal inference seriously. At
present, it is hard to know whether economic freedom affects the
environment or if some of the findings reflect reverse causality. It
could also be that both variables change with economic development and
technological innovation. The latter issue points at the need for
moderation analysis -- how does economic freedom affect the environ-
ment through various channels, such as economic growth? These and other
issues should be addressed in new studies.

To end on a positive note, just over a decade ago, the first Tesla
rolled out in California around the same time as Steve Jobs presented
Apple's iPhone. The electric car was distrusted, but at the end of 2021,
more than every second new car sold in Sweden was electric or hybrid; in
Norway, the figure was 90 percent (Kane 2022; Mobility Sweden 2023).
[The question is]{.underline} not whether it will take another 12 years
before Sweden reaches Norway's level of electric cars, but [whether
within a **few decades** we will be able count the proportion of petrol
cars on **one** or **two hands**]{.underline}. [Green technological
change is happening **quickly**]{.underline}, [and to a **large extent**
it is driven by **rich** and **free economies**]{.underline}.

The relationship between economic growth and carbon emissions is often
visualized as an inverted U-shaped curve, known as the Environmental
Kuznets Curve (EKC). This model suggests that as an economy grows,
environmental degradation first increases and then decreases after
reaching a certain level of income per capita, hence proving the
Environmental Kuznets Curve (EKC) hypothesis. [This study uses variables

**[[Stochastic]{.underline}]{.mark}** terms are explained through
**[[Wiener processes]{.underline}]{.mark}** to [[account for **random

emissions]{.underline}. The average growth rate is expected to lie in
between 1% and 5% annually, while the uncertainty in this growth ranges
from 0.5% to 2%, showing economic volatility. Baseline pollution levels
are set between 0.5 and 2 units, with pollution increasing by 0.1 to 1
units for every 1000 USD rise in GDP per capita. At the highest point of
GDP, pollution decreases by 0.05 to 0.2 units, indicating the existence
of the EKC hypothesis that economic growth initially leads to increased
pollution, but eventually results in lower emissions as GDP per capita
rises. Lastly, the uncertainty in pollution levels varies from 1% to
10%, reflecting the variability in environmental impact. This
comprehensive approach helps in understanding the dynamics between
economic development and environmental sustainability in Pakistan. The
EKC hypothesis postulates an inverted U-shaped relationship between the
level of environmental degradation and income growth. It means that in
initial stages of development, there is an inverse relationship between
pollution and GDP as the country has to develop without having concern
of environmental quality. then in later stages, pollution decreases
after reaching at threshold point, while economic development goes on.

observed relation among economic growth and environmental pollution
proposed by environmental Kuznets Curve and their studies show the
similar results and inverted U-shaped EKC with our study.

â€¢ Economic growth leads to increased pollution. During this phase, the

4\. Discussion

The outcomes of this study provides a strong evidence of the presence of
the EKC hypothesis in the case of Pakistan. With the increasing trend in
economic growth, pollution initially rises, replicating the country's
dependence on fossil fuels. However, as GDP per capita reaches USD 4500,
carbon emissions begin to decline, demonstrating the effectiveness of
investments in cleaner technologies and stricter environmental policies.
This study highlights the need for Pakistan to focus on green
technologies and sustainable economic practices to achieve long-term
environmental sustainability. In a nutshell, our findings support the
Environmental Kuznets Curve hypothesis and [[the same pattern is
observed in]{.mark} other countries]{.underline}, Apergis and Payne
(2009) employed FMLOS on [6 countries in **[Central
America]{.mark}**]{.underline} for the period of 1971 to 2004. The
results [showed the]{.underline} presence of inverted U-shaped
[EKC]{.underline}. Similarly Zhang et al. (2017) conducted a [research
on **[ten newly industrialized nations]{.mark}**]{.underline} i.e
[Brazil]{.underline}, [China]{.underline}, [Indonesia]{.underline},
[India]{.underline}, [Mexico]{.underline}, [Malaysia]{.underline}, [the
Philippines]{.underline}, [Thailand]{.underline}, [Turkey]{.underline},
[and South Africa]{.underline}. from 1971 to 2013, the research also
[proved the]{.underline} existence of hypothetical inverted U-shaped
[EKC]{.underline}. [Another study]{.underline} conducted by Ang (2007)
showed an evidence of inverted U shaped EKC. This study [used quadratic
model specification on the data of **[France]{.mark}**]{.underline} from
1960 to 2000. Omisakin (2009) applied OLS technique on [the data of
**[Nigeria]{.mark}**]{.underline} over the time period of 1970 to 2005,
it also [showed the]{.underline} existence of inverted U shaped
[EKC]{.underline}. Hence proved that our findings are consistent with
the existing literature available on environmental Kuznets Curve.

[[With]{.underline}]{.mark} the help of [our mathematical
model]{.underline}, [where]{.underline} the two variables and their
[[stochastic equations]{.mark} with drift terms capture these dynamics
to a **great extent**]{.underline}, [[we gain **valuable
insights**]{.mark} into the relationship between economic growth and
carbon emissions]{.underline}. The drift term of type in the equation
for GDP per capita captures the average growth rate of the economy,
while the drift term of type in the equation for pollution level per
capita effectively represents the complex dynamics of increasing
emissions during early economic growth and the subsequent reduction in
emissions as cleaner technologies are adopted. These equations provide a
comprehensive framework to understand and predict how economic
activities impact environmental outcomes over time, aligning well with
the Environmental Kuznets Curve hypothesis.

2\. Literature Review

Increased [concerns about **environmental [sustainability]{.mark}** have
arisen due to]{.underline} the rise in greenhouse gas [**emissions**
and]{.underline} worsening **[environmental problems]{.underline}**
resulting from development. The relationship between economic growth,
environmental quality, and energy consumption has been extensively
studied, with the EKC being one prominent theory. However, conclusive
findings regarding this nexus remain elusive. Studies such as \[9-11\]
argued that environmental degradation is not a significant concern
during a country\'s economic development phase. On the other hand,
\[12\] suggested that C02 emissions, energy consumption, and economic
growth are interrelated, with a long-term equilibrium being reached
after approximately 11 years. Long-run analyses conducted by \[13\]
indicated that energy consumption and economic growth have a
statistically significant impact on environmental degradation.

Recent research has increasingly recognized the crucial role of energy
consumption as a determinant of environmental degradation, as
highlighted in \[14, 15\]. Energy consumption contributes to C02
emissions \[16\] and is a leading cause of environmental issues \[17\].
Similar findings regarding the long-term relationship between energy
consumption and economic growth have been observed by \[18-22\]. For
instance, \[21\] focused on leading emerging economies (South Korea,
Russia, India and China), while \[22\] examined data from 188 countries.

[Addressing the **challenge** of reducing energy consumption **per
capita** while maintaining **economic growth**]{.underline}, \[23\]
[suggested that technological **advancements**]{.underline},
particularly the adoption of energy-saving technologies, [offer
potential **solutions**]{.underline}. However, the mass adoption of
capital-driven production techniques in the industrial sector may lead
to increased C02 emissions \[24,25\].

[[Previous]{.mark} **empirical [studies]{.mark}** predominantly employed
**panel data regression** techniques but often **[overlook]{.mark}**ed
the **[c]{.mark}**ross-**[s]{.mark}**ection **[d]{.mark}**ependence
effect. Neglecting this effect can [lead to **inefficient**]{.mark} and
**inconsistent [estimates]{.mark}**]{.underline}, as discussed by
\[26\]. [Correlated effects among **regressors** can further contribute
to **[biased conclusions]{.mark}**]{.underline}. Heterogeneous [models
investigating the **relationship** between energy and economic growth
are relatively **limited** compared to **other studies**]{.underline}.
For instance, \[27\] explored GDP and C02 emissions in middle-income
economies from 1980 to 2012, finding that energy consumption played a
crucial role in upper and lower-middle-income countries. \[28\],
covering the period from 1975 to 2015, examined eight developing
countries and discovered an inverted U-shaped relationship between
energy intensity and industrialization/urbanization. Additionally,
\[29\] investigated 20 OECD countries from 1870 to 2014 and identified a
link between environmental degradation and growth using various
estimators.

The [[STIRPAT]{.mark} model has been **widely used** in environmental
**studies** to analyse the **relationship** between human activities and
various **environmental issues**, including **pollution**]{.underline}.
The [[flexibility]{.underline}]{.mark} of the STIRPAT model [[is]{.mark}
one of its **[key advantage]{.mark}**s, as it [allows]{.mark} for the
incorporation, modification, and [breakdown of **various**]{.mark}
**influencing [factors]{.mark}** that are **relevant** to the
analysis]{.underline} \[30\]. Several past studies have employed the
STIRPAT model to investigate different aspects of pollution \[31-35\].
\[31\] analysed selected Asian countries and highlighted the potential
increase in C02 emissions due to carbonintensive activities and
industrialization. \[32,34\] extended the STIRPAT model in cross-country
analyses, with \[34\] exploring different fossil fuel sources and their
impact on the environment, while \[36\] identified a reduction in
emissions among 18 developed countries due to increased renewable energy
consumption and improved energy intensity. Furthermore, \[33\] studied
the relationship between population, GDP, and emissions in Taiwan,
finding that population growth had a positive effect on emissions while
GDP had a negative effect. \[35\] discussed the differential impacts of
population growth and economic growth on the environment based on a
sample of 84 countries. Conversely, \[36\] found that energy consumption
had a larger impact on environmental quality than economic growth and
urbanization in China, utilizing a spatial-temporal approach not
considered in previous STIRPAT literature. \[37\] investigated the
impact of various driving forces on C02 emissions in several prominent
ASEAN countries. The sample included Myanmar, Singapore, Malaysia,
Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia and the data covered the period
from 1992 to 2016. The study employed panel data modelling techniques,
specifically fixed effect regression estimation, random effect
regression estimation, and pooled ordinary least squares (OLS)
estimation. The dependent variable in the study was C02 emissions, while
the independent variables among others are population, GDP, urban
population and C02 intensity. The study\'s findings indicated that GDP,
as a measure of affluence, and environmental patent count, as an
indicator of technology, were important driving factors of C02 emissions
in the ASEAN region.

Abbasi et al., \[38\] used an extended STIRPAT model to examine the
relationship between energy use, urbanization and carbon emissions in
Asian countries. The results of the FMOLS and DOLS methods confirm the
long-run direction among the variables. It is observed that energy
consumption and urbanization have a positive impact on C02 emissions and
economic output. Additionally, the study reveals that financial
development has a negative effect on C02 emissions but a positive effect
on economic growth. The Granger causality test suggests the existence of
long-run causal relationships among the variables. Considering the
interdependencies among countries, similar to our study, \[39\] employed
the AMG and CCEMG estimators within the STIRPAT framework.

The [analysis begins by conducting several **[statistical

After confirming the presence of CSD, the [**stationarity** of the

tests]{.underline} \[49\]. These tests account for the CSD effect when

To analyse the relationship described in Eq. (3), heterogeneous
estimators, namely mean group (MG), augmented mean group (AMG), and
common correlated effect mean group (CCEMG) estimators, are employed.
The AMG and CCEMG estimators consider the cross-section dependence (CSD)
effect, while the MG estimator does not account for this effect. All
mean group type estimators follow a similar approach:

The MG estimator, developed by \[51\], allows for parameter
heterogeneity by separately estimating OLS regressions for each panel.
The [average of the coefficients is then **calculated** to estimate the
**mean parameters** across groups]{.underline}. This [estimator exhibits
**consistent performance** when the sample size and time-period
dimension are **sufficiently large**]{.underline}. The CCEMG estimator,
introduced by \[52\], is an extension of the MG estimator. Unlike the MG
estimator, the CCEMG estimator takes into account the CSD effect and
offers robustness against slope heterogeneity and endogeneity. Moreover,
the CCEMG estimator is robust to structural breaks, non-stationarity,
and noncointegration, even for smaller sample sizes. In the CCEMG
estimator, the average of the variables is calculated for the entire
panel, and each equation includes the average cross-section terms of
both y and x. The AMG estimator, originally introduced by \[53\] and
further developed by \[54\], is specifically designed to address both
CSD and slope heterogeneity. The AMG estimator incorporates a \"common
dynamic process\" variable. The AMG estimator is unbiased and remains
efficient regardless of the dimensions of the sample and time-period,
making it robust to changes in degrees of freedom.

4\. Conclusion

This study aims to investigate the long-term factors that affect
pollution among ASEAN countries by considering interdependence and
verifying if the EKC exists. The finding from heterogeneous models
provides valuable insights into the relationship between various factors
and environmental degradation and cross-section dependence among
selected ASEAN countries. The results showed that an extended factor of
the STIRPAT model, trade openness has a significant and negative impact
on C02 emissions, indicating that increased trade can contribute to
reducing pollution levels. This suggests that international trade can
serve as a mechanism for the transfer of cleaner technologies and
practices, leading to improved environmental outcomes.

Additionally, [the presence of a **positive** and **significant**
cross-section dependence effect for **C02 emissions**]{.underline},
[suggests **interdependence**]{.underline} or similarity in the
behaviour of emissions across countries. [**[Ignoring]{.mark}** this
[effect]{.mark} may [lead to **biased**]{.mark} and **inconsistent
[estimations]{.mark}**, underscoring the **importance** of considering
**c**ross-**s**ection **d**ependence in future research]{.underline}.

pattern**]{.underline}. This suggests that [as countries experience
